data.question: What is the chemical formula of the compound that undergoes a phase transition at 357 K?
data.answer: [CH3CH2NH3][Cu(HCOO)3]

data.question: What are the two phases involved in the phase transition of [CH3CH2NH3][Cu(HCOO)3]?
data.answer: The two phases are LTHD perovskite and HTLD diamond.

data.question: What triggers the phase transition from LTHD perovskite to HTLD diamond in [CH3CH2NH3][Cu(HCOO)3]?
data.answer: Heating triggers the phase transition from LTHD perovskite to HTLD diamond.

data.question: Can the reverse phase transition from HTLD diamond to LTHD perovskite in [CH3CH2NH3][Cu(HCOO)3] be induced by cooling?
data.answer: No, the reverse phase transition cannot be induced by cooling but can be induced by compression.

data.question: What structural changes occur in [CH3CH2NH3][Cu(HCOO)3] during the phase transition?
data.answer: The rearrangement of one long copper–formate bond, the switch of bridging-chelating mode of the formate, the alternation of N¢H···O H-bonds, and the flipping of ethylammonium are involved in the transition.

data.question: Is the HTLD phase of [CH3CH2NH3][Cu(HCOO)3] polar or non-polar?
data.answer: The HTLD phase is non-polar.

data.question: What is the role of strong N¢H···O H-bonds in the phase transition of [CH3CH2NH3][Cu(HCOO)3]?
data.answer: The strong N¢H···O H-bonds probably lock the metastable HTLD phase, preventing the reverse transition under ambient or lower pressure.

data.question: How are the magnetic properties of the LTHD and HTLD phases of [CH3CH2NH3][Cu(HCOO)3] described?
data.answer: Both phases are spin-canted antiferromagnets of different characters.

data.question: Does the LTHD phase of [CH3CH2NH3][Cu(HCOO)3] exhibit ferroelectric properties?
data.answer: True, the LTHD phase is polar and ferroelectric.

data.question: What happens to the dielectric constant of the LTHD phase of [CH3CH2NH3][Cu(HCOO)3] as it approaches the transition temperature?
data.answer: The dielectric constant of the LTHD phase increases slowly and then quickly rises to a maximum around the transition temperature.

data.question: Is the HTLD phase of [CH3CH2NH3][Cu(HCOO)3] thermally stable at room temperature?
data.answer: True, the HTLD phase is stable at room temperature for a long time.

data.question: What method was used to prepare the green-blue LTHD crystals of [CH3CH2NH3][Cu(HCOO)3]?
data.answer: The green-blue LTHD crystals were prepared by a solution method.

data.question: What confirms the phase purity of [CH3CH2NH3][Cu(HCOO)3]?
data.answer: The phase purity was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD).

data.question: Is the backward transition from HTLD to LTHD in [CH3CH2NH3][Cu(HCOO)3] a first-order transition?
data.answer: False, the document does not specify the order of the backward transition, only the forward transition is indicated as a probable first-order transition.

data.question: What happens to the cavity volume of [CH3CH2NH3][Cu(HCOO)3] during the phase transition?
data.answer: The cavity volume increases from 62 Å3 in LTHD to 80 Å3 in HTLD.

data.question: Does the thermal treatment of LTHD phase of [CH3CH2NH3][Cu(HCOO)3] result in the formation of HTLD phase?
data.answer: True, the blue HTLD phase is obtained by thermal treatment of LTHD.

data.question: What is the role of pressure in the phase transition of [CH3CH2NH3][Cu(HCOO)3]?
data.answer: Pressure can induce the backward transition from HTLD to LTHD.

data.question: How does the structure of [CH3CH2NH3][Cu(HCOO)3] change from LTHD to HTLD phase?
data.answer: The structure changes from a perovskite to a diamond structure, involving bond rearrangement and flipping of ethylammonium.

data.question: What experimental evidence supports the phase transition in [CH3CH2NH3][Cu(HCOO)3]?
data.answer: The DSC runs revealed an irreversible transition under ambient pressure, and variable-temperature PXRD confirmed the phase transition.

data.question: Is the phase transition in [CH3CH2NH3][Cu(HCOO)3] reversible by cooling under ambient pressure?
data.answer: False, the phase transition is not reversible by cooling under ambient or lower pressure.
